div.head: Englih PILLS FOR THE SCURVY, And all other Cutaneous Dieaes, or Breakings out of the Body, Sores, &c. from that or any other Caues.
div.p: AMONGST all the Dieaes incident to Humane Bodies, there is none more predominant (tho' leat regarded) than the Scurvy, a Dieae that eems incident to this Climate, and which pares none of any Age, Sex or Contitution, being a general Malady carcely taken Notice of, becaue it eldom kills, tho at the ame time it introduces many direful Ditempers, and proves the principal and efficient Occaion thereof.

The caue of the Scurvy, is from an acid corroive Humour tainting the Blood and Juices of the Body, incumbred with Earthy Sulphurs of a Nature rebellious and tubborn, and attended ometimes (epecially when inveterate) with a very trong Smell or Stench; which Volatile Saline Acid, irritates the Nerves and Membranes, harpens the Lymph, debauches the innate Spirits of the Parts, and perverts the equal Temperature of the Blood; this is the immediate caue of the Scurvy: But the remote Caues, are the Sea-Air, and the Specifick Malignity of the Stagnated Waters and the Earth, affecting, by their corroive Effluvium's, alo
by infection, an hereditary conveyance from the Parent, and from gros, faeculent and obtructive Dyet, epecially if over-charged with Salt, or render'd hard and compact with Smoke, as dry'd Neats Tongues, Bacon, Sawcages, red Herrings, dry'd Salmon, hung Beef, &c. do not only contribute Matter, but obtain alo a peculiar faculty of impreing a Scorbutick Idea on it: Of the ame Nature are Melancholick Meats, as Beef, Pork, Geee, Ducks, Salt-fih, and all other Fih that are bred in Standing Waters, as Eeles and others; alo pickled and marinaded Fih, as pickled Herrings, Anchovies, and the like, which bears a great part in this Morbifick Production; alo a Salin Air render'd thick and contipative by Vapours and Damps, Nitrous Evaporations out of the Earth, filled with putrid Steams of Sinks, Gutters, Ditches, muddy and dirty Streets, and Sulphurous Smokes of Chimneys, tagnating and pent up between narrow Lanes and Corners, and eldom or but little erenated, or putrify'd, by the Rays of a clear hining Sun, nor frequently ventilated with Eaterly Breezes, and uch is the Clime of London, where the Air is experienced cloe, dull, damp, alin and muddy, over-pread with dene, dark, alin Clouds (attracted out of the Sea) for two Thirds, if not three Fourth Parts of the Year, during which time the Winds eldom blow Eaterly, or is favour'd with a miling Sun; the two, viz. Dyet and State of the Air, &c. are accounted by all, the principal, external and internal Agents or Caues of the Scurvy, agreing the Body both within and without; the firt by making its efforts on the Stomach and its Ferment, thereby aaulting the Blood and animal Liquor; and the latter, by entring the external Pores by their ubtle effluvium's, as is mot certainly and at large et forth in a late ingenious Tract, entituled, Scelera Aquarum; Wherein the Author tells us,

q.p:
That London is ituated on a wicked Bottom of Earth called blue Clay; this Bottom is many contiguous, tho' eparated Bodies, extends it elf round the Metropolis and Lines of Communication ome Miles in Circumference, and reacheth likewie downwards to
an enormous Depth towards the Center; for the boreings that have been frequently made by the Brewers in quet of the impregnated Water (called Spring Liquor) hath been motly attempted to thirty and forty Fathom Depth without ucces.

As all orts of Clay are found by Experience and Obervations of Country Farmers and Brewers, to abound with a Juice or Salt of an Eurine Acid Nature and Quality, which vitiates all the Fruits of the Earth, except it be firt weetned and heath'd by Chalk both crude and calcin'd into Lime; o this blue kind of Glebe more celerous and corroive than all the other, maleficates equally Air and Water, and renders all the tagnate Waters of the Neighbourhood eurine to a very high degree.

And here it is that the bounty of Nature hath made it elf remarkable to the Eye, in burying this bottom of Clay near twenty foot in depth under Ground; and beides, covering it over and over with repeated Strata of diffe â€¢ ent kinds of Moulds towards the Gravelly Surface of the Earth, left the Atmophere hould be invaded, and the ambient Air we apire, hould be thereby exaperated and rendred Catarrhous, through the corroive effluvia ent up from below; o that till about One Hundred and Fifty Years ago, when an endles number of Perforations began to be made by the common Brewers into the Subterranean World, the City of London enjoyed its Native State of Health, and was entirely free from Coughs and Catarrhs, Periodical Fevers, vulgarly call'd Agues; and in a word, from all the Symtomatical Branches of the Scurvy, hitherto enumerated.

And here it may be oberved by the by, that the acrid Effluvia ent up from the Clayey Bottom, by reaon of their volatile Nature, do little harm in the Summer Seaon; but during that of the Winter, whilt they are weighed down and reverberated back towards the Bafis of the Atmophere by the Fogs and Frots; then I may ay it is, and not till then, that they begin to Bite even Perons adult, bur more epecially
the uneaon'd Bodies of Children and Foreigners.

In hort, the Scelus Aquoe & Loci, or corrupted or corroive Waters, here inited on; lept for a long Succeion of Ages, out of Harms way in the Bowels of the Subterranean World; and beides, the corroive Waters were not employed either in Bread or potable Liquors extracted forth of Malt: And, as I may add, they were only made ue of for clearing of the Sight, and for eating away the Kells and Cataracts off of dim Eyes.

But about the Acceion of Queen Elizabeth to the Crown (as I am well inform'd) Clay Waters began to grow into credit with uch as Brewed or Baked for Sale, as a more powerful-Mentruum, for extracting the Tincture out of Malt: And at that period of Time, it was that the Waters of D AT C. were Carted from Hogdon to the everal Brew-houes in the Metropolis, or City of London, at 800 l. per Ann. Expence; and at the ame time a world of Wells were made, and Pumps erected at every corner of the City and Suburbs.

In a word, the Scelus Aquoe & Loci, now poken of, that is to ay, the acrid Nature and eurine Quality of the Stagnate Waters in and about this City, is ufficiently evinced a Poteriori from the ill natur'd Effects thereof in all Dometick Ues. Firt, in chopping and ditching of Hands and Face: Secondly, from coagulating of Alcalous Fluids, both Soap and Barm: Thirdly, from hardening of Peae and redning of Bacon, and all Fleh Meats, if boiled therein; which the Lord Bacon enumerates amongt ill Signs and Diagnotick of Inalubrity or Unwholomnes: Fourthly, from the killing of Flowers and detroying all manner of Garden-tuff, unles the acid Salt be rt fievaporated by open Airings and Inolations on the Surface of the Earth, as was practied by the Ancients, and put in practice by Gardeners to this Day.

I had almot forgot to add here, that the prodigious bottom of Clay now poken of, extends it elf
from the Metropolis, or City of London, all along the Banks of the River Thames, into the Marhes or Flats of Eex, which vitiates both Air and Water in the Hundreds to a very high degree, whereby the Foundation hath been laid of uch Chronical Fevers, and Scorbutick Agues, as inceently reign in the Ditricts of Dench and Rochefort. In a word, the River of Thames is alo vitiated by Dyers, &c. o that no Water is fit for Bread and Brewer's ue, ave the New River, which is far more Salubrious or Healthful than any other Water in or about the City of London.

div.p: However, the Scurvy; whether from immediate or remote Caues, is certainly a Corruption and Putrefaction of the Blood and Humours; whence the Concoction being hurt, the Stomach (which is the Index of Dieaes) is depraved, Obtructions of the Liver and Spleen, &c. are occaion'd, bringing, by degrees, a general Cachexie, or evil Habit of Body; whereby manifold and complicated Ditempers are at length introduced, which affects all Perons according to their various and different Tempers and Contitutions.

Such I ay is the Scurvy, that grand Enemy to Health, and only reigning Dieae of this Kingdom, which Perons of all Ranks, Ages and Sexes are more or les afflicted with, it being the original and productive Caue of almot all the Ditempers incident to Humane Bodies; and from which alone Dieae (if not timely removed) more epecially proceed Rheumatims, Gouts, Fevers, Agues, Jaundice, Green-icknes, Dropies, Cholicks, Stone and Gravel, Phtyicks, Conumptions, Convulions, Apoplexies, Palfies, Hectick Fevers, Hypochondriack Melancholly, Hyterick Paion, Vapours, Fits of the Mother, Rickets in Children, Kings-evil, Falling Sicknes, and the like, which thee Pills, if taken, both prevents and Cures; their Reputation having, by their manifold Vertues, been kept up for many Years, and accounted the only Sovereign Medicine in the whole Art of Phyick, againt all Scorbutick Ditempers whatoever; they penetrating, in a very hort pace, the whole Humane Body from Head to Foot;
and tho' they never till now were made publick to the World, yet many Thouands of Boxes have been dipered with wonderful Succes, not only here in England, but alo in Germany, Holland, and other remote Countries, where that devouring Dieae, the Scurvy, hath likewie predominated, they being o certain a Cure for that tubborn and rebellious Dieae, that Thouands have been cured, when the Ditemper has grown o inveterate and deplorable, as to become a hame and candal to thoe that have had it, and which hath been taken by many to be ome bad Ditemper; for the Scurvy often caues great Pains in the Head, Noe, Shoulders, Arms, Hips, Legs, and Bones, with the Sciatick and other tormenting Pains all over the whole Body, whereby they leep ill, and tumble and tos in the Night with great uneaines and trouble, and are attended with a heavines and wearines, having reddih or blueih Spots or Breakings out on the Skin, weaknes in the Back, Loyns and Knees, a bad Stomach, and ometimes los of Appetite, trong or tinking Breath, looenes or forenes of the Teeth and Gums, Throat and Mouth, with Itchings, Pimples, Blotches, Boiles, Ulcers, Morphews, Scabs, Scurf, a general Weaknes and Faintnes over the whole Body; the Scurvy mot commonly afflicting People after various means, and ometimes with Vomitings, Looenees, and the diguie of almot innumerable Ditempers, according to their Contitutions, different Situations and Places where they dwell, and o reemble all manner of Illes, too tedious here to enumerate, as that its no wonder their Dieaes are o frequently mitaken, and doth, with o much violence and force, oftentimes wander about the Body and affect it, that if it be neglected, it will at lat get into the Bones, and infect the very Marrow thereof, yet notwithtanding (o famous are thee mot excellent Pills) the Cure then will be performed, by only a few times more than ordinary taking of them.

Tho' it is advised, that upon the appearance of any of thoe Symptoms, you have peedy recoure to thee Pills, which will prevent their increae, and carry them
off with les trouble and difficulty; there being carce one Dieae which People are afflicted with here in this Climate, but the principal and efficient Caue thereof is the Scurvy, that Dieae carrying Thouands to their Graves, when it carcely has been known-of what Ditempers they have dy'd, there being very few that dicerns, or indeed will give, themelves the trouble to conider what the original Caue or occaion thereof is, tho' it too manifetly appears (as every judicious Phyician may dicover, if he will,) that it is the Scurvy. Therefore be well advis'd about your Ditemper, and run not into the Hands of inconiderate Practitioners, who take not due Thoughts about the original Caue; for how many, both Old and Young, are daily carried off by Fevers, Rheumatiins, Apoplexies, Conumptions, Convulions, Rickets, King's-evil, and the like; which, if the original Caue had been conulted, and timely recoure had to thee famous Pills, might in all probability have been alive to this day; thee Pills being very harmles and afe, and proves the only Univeral, Purgative, Preervative, Preventative and Curative Remedy, in the whole Republick of Medicine.

They wonderfully, o far as any Purging Medicine can prevent and cure the Dropy and Gout peedily (thoe Dieaes being the product of the Scurvy) taking away the Water in one, and the Pain in the other, tho' never o great, and not only gives preent Eae, Relief, and Comfort in the Gout, and that beyond expectation, but alo very much leens, if not totally prevents the Pains returning for the future, they working gently by Stool and Urine, and ometimes by Vomit, if the Stomach be very foul, without the leat Griping or making ick; thereby curing mot curable Dieaes, by tirring up and dicharging thoe lurking, offending Humours, weetning the Mas of Blood and Juices, and bringing the ill and untoward Habit of Body into a good, ound and firm Dipoition: Thee Pills having cured numbers of Perons both of Dropies and Gouts, and that in a very hort time; ome of which have been given over as incurable, others have gone above

Thee Pills being endowed with uch excellent Properties, and are o full and effectual a healer, that they deervedly merit the Title of the only univeral Pills in the World.

Thee Pills are of an admirable and friendly quality, performing all its Operations as-Nature-her elf requires, and is dipoed to the Action, tho' chiefly by Stool and Urine, o that they are bound to that way of Operation as bet erves Nature's end in retoring Health: Hence it is, that they cure Dieaes with o great afety, peed and eae, and that without almot any other Medicine, they being (as was aid before) fitted for all Ages, Sexes and Contitutions whatoever; and that if there but little Corruption in the Body, they bring forth but little, if much, they bring forth much, and in Perons perfectly well, they will carcely work at all, becaue in uch they have no Enemy to meet or contend withal.

And this they do not only by fighting or contending with the Dieae after a rugged and robut manner, but in a paive way, by glancing, as it were, and piercing of it with the ubtilty of their Effluviums, and as it were by charming of it, undoes it in its very Root and Eence, whereby the Dieay Matter being melted and changed in its Nature, Dieaes and the very Seeds of of them inenibly vanih away, thereby curing thoe Ditempers which are almot incredible to relate.

But no more need to be aid of their Vertues, only give me leave to add, that thee Pills are cheap, eay approved helps, free from the leat danger upon any account whatoever; are afe and benign in their Compoition, rational in their Preparation, amicable and adapted to all Contitutions, mot powerful againt thoe Dieaes to which they are appropriated; able to tand the tet of all Tryals, and have an uncontroulable Probatum et continually attending them, they being made of nothing that neither naueates the Stomach, or tortures the Patient, but operates Cito, Tuto & Fucunde, even when many other Medicines of far greater Names, have wofully failed: Their gratefulnes to the Senes and Animal Spirits are uch, as will invite as well as ait all the Powers of Nature to withtand the Dieaes, and by the ubtilty of their Temper, pemetrate into thoe cloe Recees where the Roots of Ditempers uually lodge, and into which the common, dull and earthy Preparations, o frequently ued in practice can never poibly enter or reach into; but as Experience is the bet Schoolmater, I leave every one to make Tryal and judge as they find, and accordingly to commend or dipraie them to their Neighbours and Friends, not doubting but they will perform what is herein aerted, without hazard of Body, Pure or Expectation, as ome Thouands in this Kingdom can, upon their own Knowledge, tetify, what is aid of them, being no Rhodomontade Story to raie a Penny, nor guilded Buh to et off bad Wine, but Matter of Fact, back'd with uch number of Experiences, as not to leave the leat umbrage or hadow of Fality or Pretence.

div.head: A LINIMENT FOR Sore, Swell'd or Cancerated BREASTS IN WOMEN, WITH THEIR Nature, Caue, &c.
div.p:
IT is not my deign to write any thing here concerning Cancers in any part of the Body, ave only thoe that happen in the Breats of Women, wherein I hall to the meanet Capacity, hew the difference between thoe that really are, and thoe that are only imagined, or reputed to be Cancerous; whereby the Mitakes too common, may be prevented, and Ruine to the Patient aved; when the Name is now o frequent, and the fear of it o dreadful, that not one well'd or pained Breat in Twenty, but is preently
thought o, and every Goody Nure, Doctres or Midwife, will pronounce o right or wrong, and conequently has a never failing Remedy for Cure, which upon applying, produces a Cancer, where no uch thing perhaps had been.

A Cancer is as much as to a Crab, and is a hard painful Tumour, either Whole or Ulcerous, and is aid to have its rie from many Caues; ome ay from ill Diet, Meats of ill Juice, of a hot quality, and thick and glutinous ubtance, and that Onions, Leeks, Garlick, Venion and hot Spic'd Meats, eat too plentifully, and hot fiery Liquors, that burn and make adut the Blood and Humours, uch as Brandy, trong Wines, &c. immoderately drank, breed them. Others, that the Air, perturbations of the Mind, Melancholly, ill Habits of Body, hot, harp Humours, where there is a dicrays of the Blood and Lympha, being fill'd with an Acrimonious Salt, and a malign Sulphur is their occaion. Others, that they eldom proceed but from Blows, Strokes, Punches, or uch external Violence, ill handling, Tumours from curdled Milk upon Lyings in, Impothumes, &c. by which means there being an acid Ferment in the Blood, or it may be Obtructions of the Terms, or ome other illnes, which oftentimes caues Humours to flow thither, where coagulating, is capable to produce a Cancerous Germen, epecially upon ill management, o as in time it increaes and arrives to to that degree of inveteracy, which we ometimes find them to be.

Having now accounted for the caue of Cancers in the Breats, we come to their Definitions, and are preternatural Tumours of a hard, lumpy, round or unequal Subtance; of a livid or black Colour, having great Veins every way round it, which the Blood extends and makes turgid and viible, reembling the Feet of a Crab, from whence it took its Name, and is full of Pain, and very hot, and of a cruel and horrid Apect; and ometimes ries to uch a hight of Malignity, that the Matter it contains when it is broke, is as harp and as corroive as Aqua Fortis.

They are, as aid at firt, Whole or Ulcerous; in the beginning, growing or increaing, they are generally whole, but when come to ripenes, they break, run or gleet, and are then called Cancer Ulceratus, or Ulcus Canceratum. This Humour being fixt upon ome one or more of the Glands of the Breat, from either of the Caues mentioned, and being harp and corroive, is apt to convert whatever comes to it of Blood, into the ame Acrimony with it elf, and o increaes apace, while the Skin is whole; but much more when upon the breaking of the Skin, for then the acceion of the Airs adds to the vigour of the Ferment, when it grows fierce or enraged, and o hoots forth it elf in the nature of a Fungus, or Excrecences, or Tubercles, &c. This part being deprav'd, and a vitious Ferment therein, the Humours that flow thither, are till farther changed, till at length they partake of a malign and poionous Nature, vehemently deleterious, coniting of a tinking Arenical Sulphur, and a Catheretick, or highly corroive Salt, extreamly ubtle and penetrating.

This malign Humour, when o from whatever Caues, chiefly take up its eat in parts that are Glandulous, beginning in the Glandule of a Part, and mot often affects Womens Breats, by reaon of their looenes, great Humidities, and trong Ferment they contain, and at firt is very difficult to be known; for it at firt exceeds not the bignes of a Pea or a Bean, which in time increaes lowly to the bignes of an Egg or a Melon, or as ometimes it has been known as big as a Pompion, tho again in ome, according as is the Caue, it grows big of a udden, and dicovers its evil Nature by the grievous Symptoms that appear, and a â€¢ it increaes in bignes, it increaes in malignity.

In the Cure of Cancers, various Succees have happen'd, which have divided the Opinions of Practitioners concerning the Caues of them. The Ancients oberv'd, that Women were mot troubled with Cancers, upon the topping of their Monthly Viits, and that when at any time they had wellings in their Breats, upon the provocation of that Evacuation, the wellings
either unk or left thin, from whence they concluded, that the topping of that Coure in Women, was the only Caue thereof; and this they endeavour'd to explain, by aying that the Blood, by uch toppages being not purify'd from the Atribilious Humour or Acids, which eparate themelves from it, by the regular flowing of the Coures, dicharge themelves upon ome one of the Glandulous Parts, and thoe of the Breat, more generally, from the Communication there is between them and the Womb, which Communication Experience confirms, becaue we ee that jut upon, or a little before the coming down of the Coures, the Breats of Women are tender; that is, the Glandules or Kernels of them, o as not to be handled or pres'd with eae, which upon the flowing of the Coures, that tendernes leaves them, and they may be felt and handled without any manner of uneaines, o that it is plain, that upon the toppage of the Coures in Women, Cancers are oftentimes occaion'd, epecially where the Blood abounds with Atrabilious Humours or Acids. I ay ometimes it is o, for it mut not be aid to be always o, becaue we have intances without number, of Women that have had them by Blows, Bruies, &c. as before we have made mention of; and as was the cae of a Gentlewoman, whoe Husband after a Drunken Bout was thrown into a Fever, and being delirious, upon her giving him omething to drink, he hit her Left Breat with his Hand, which caus'd it to Cancerate, of which he oon after dy'd. We are aur'd by many obervations, that Cancers ometimes have proceeded from the topping of the Monthly Viits, by Frights, violent Grief, and by letting of Blood uneaonably at the times of the Coures actually running, which are dangerous topping them, and care hould be forthwith taken to bring them to flow again, or ele the Breats may be affected, epecially if the Blood abounds with Atrabilious Humours or Acids as before-mentioned.

The hardnes of Cancers is from the thicknes of the Humour; the pain of them is from the conjoyn'd Caue, it being harp and corroive; the Heat of them proceeds
from the extremity of Pain; the livid or blackh colour is from the Malignity and Poion, which even dicolours the puret Metals, if touch'd with it; the roundnes of the Cancers is from the thicknes of the Matter, which cannot pread it elf abroad as Humours do that are more fluid; the inequality of hape of the Cancerous Tumour, as ometimes 3 or 4 quare, or longih proceeds from the Ferment of the Humour, and becaue ometimes it is contain'd in everal little Glands; and its turgid Veins, like to Crab's Claws, is caued from the Recrements of the Blood filling thoe Parts, which by reaon of Matter obtructing or preing upon them, hinders its getting forth.

Cancers are known in part by the Places they fix on, which are the Glands, tho' they may breed in almot all parts of the Body; and this Aegineta confirms, who ays, a Cancer may happen to undry Places, as the Lips, Tongue, Cheeks, Womb, and other looe Glandulous Parts; but were One has a Cancer in any part beides, Twenty have them in their Breats; and o ays Galen, That Cancerous Tumours are chiefly in Women's Breats, which have not their Purgations according to Nature, and the reaon eems to be from the conent of the Parts, as before oberved; for that the Mammariae Veins, or Veins of the Breats, meet with the Uterinae, or Veins of the Womb under the Muculi recti of the Belly, by which means there is a tranlation of the Matter from the Womb to the Breats.

Where Cancers in the Breats are painful, there is alo attending a Pulation, or beating like a Pule, together with a Heat more than ordinary; and where the Pains are very harp, o as if the Part was truck with a Dart, <> the Matter is very corroive, and will certainly in a little time break forth in a Gleeting or ome dangerous tinking Ulcer; and when they are Ulcerated, as frequently they are, from the breaking of ome of the Tubercls lying under the Skin, whether the Matter that runs be much or little, the Ulcer is painful and very tinking, and not only dicharge a tinking Gleety Humour, but alo there thruts forth
hard and painful Lips, which in time, if not rightly managed, fixes to the Ribs (that is, if the Cancer be in the Breat or ide of it) becoming, by the quick progres it makes, of a horrible and frightful appearance.

Such Cancers ometimes bleed, either through the eruption of ome Veels, or from the harp corroive Nature of the Humour, which gnaws the Veels aunder; tho' I have known them to bleed while they have been whole, the Blood iuing through the Nipple, or ome mall Pin-hole. Some Cancers again, that are Ulcerated, end forth a Fungus or flehy Excrecencies; other conume and eat away all the Fleh about them, after a wonderful, and indeed dreadful manner; and both thee often bleed, and that in great quanties ometime, becaue the Capillary Veels are by the corroding quality of a Cancer, eaten aunder, whence the flux of Blood is o great, that the trength of the Patient is quickly pent, and the Spirits being exhauted and conumed, they oon dye; as a poor Woman did that I knew, after labouring under a Cancerated Breat very painful, for near two Years, and could all that while have no Remedy; for indeed uch are very rarely to be cur'd, and if at all, it is by Surgery; that is, by cutting off the Breat in time, which the Woman I mention was by many Surgeons advis'd to, but would not ubmit to the Operation.

Thoe inveterate and dangerous Cancers but eldom happen, and is frequently more from want of timely and proper Applications than the Nature of them; for they are oftentimes aggravated and enraged, and the Humour, by wrong Applications inwardly and outwardly, made corroive and harp, as we frequently find it to be; and the Humour is <> corroive, it is as ubtle, quick and penetrating as Poion it elf, as will appear from the following Relation, which a Surgeon tells us happened upon himelf, who was by Name Mr. Samuel Smith, one of the Surgeons of St Thomas's Hopital in Southwark, who at the cutting off of a large Cancerated Breat, had (after the Breat was off) a Curioity to tate the Juice, or Matter contain'd
in one of the little Cytis's or Glands of the ame, which he did by touching it with one of his Fingers, and then tating it from the ame with his Tongue, the Tate of which he proteted did immediately like a Gas, pierce through the whole ubtance of his Tongue, and paed down his Throat not les harp or biting than Oyl of Vitriol, Spirit of Nitre, or Aquae Fortis, or ome vehement Catheretick, or Cautick Salt, and altho' he preently pit out, and wah'd his Mouth with Water, and that oftentimes, and alo with Wine, and drank preently very freely of Wine after it, yet could not get rid of the Tate thereof, but it continued with him, and brought him (who was a very trong Man) into a Conumption, or wating pining Condition, attended with everal other ill Symptoms, which in a few Months after killed him, the Tate thereof never going off from his Tongue to his dying Hour; and that the Tate of the Juice, or Matter of that Cancerated Breat, he declared upon his Death-bed, and near the lat Moments of his Life, to be the true and only Caue of his languihing Condition and Death.

Galen tells us, and the ame is confirmed by daily Experience, that Cancers in the outward Parts, as in the Breat, may in the beginning be cur'd, but when they are come to a coniderable bignes, oftentimes will yield to no Remedy but extirpation; indeed a palliative Cure may be precrib'd, which, if the Cancer be not Ulcerated, may make the Patient eay, and prolong Life, o as not to dye the ooner, becaue of that Cancer; but when it is Ulcerated, it can never be cicatried, but as long as it o remains, the Patient will live in continual Pain and Filthines, and at lat dye mierably, unles it is cur'd by Ution, Cautry, or Extirpation, and then may prove but a doubtful Cure.

If a Cancer in the Breat proceeds from malignant Humours or corroive Salts in the Blood, it is generally incurable, by reaon of its malignant and poyonous Ferment, which eldom yields to any internal and external Remedies, whether Vomiting, Purging, Bleeding, Sweating, Dyet-drink; nay Salivations, or application
of Annodines, Suppuratives, or any other kind of Medicine; or if in ome it hould eem to yield, or indeed eem to be cur'd, while it proceeds from thoe corroive Humours, they many times breed again, and break forth afreh, either in the ame place, or in ome other parts of the Body.

But if a Cancer proceeds from external Caues, as Bruies, Blows, &c. and be taken in time, and the hurt lies not very deep, a Cure, with good Succes, may be undertaken, yea oftentimes tho' they lie deep; but then mut be with proper Applications; for wrong Medicines apply'd, tho' the Injury be but mall, is increas'd to what, of it elf it might never have came to, therefore is a caution worthy to be taken notice of; many Women, by undue tampering, and ill advice and Medicines, having been ruin'd, and lot their Lives, which otherwie, in all likelihood, might have been preerv'd: Therefore before external Applications be made to a Cancerated Breat, or uppoed Cancerated Breats, it ought to be conider'd whether it be recent and mall, or inveterate and great; if the firt, it will by proper Applications, admit of Cure, (I ay proper Applications, becaue by and by I hall come to relate what is the mot proper to apply to a true Cancer, or an imagin'd Cancer of the Breat) if the econd, it never will admit of Cure without cutting. A pallative Cure may be had, if it be not ulcerated, as aid before, where, by proper Remedies, Eae may be had and Life prolong'd, and that done by divers Medicines, at leat every Nure, or good Woman has a Medicine, and that if you will believe them, they ay will cure; but thoe hap-hazzard Remedies I have known fatal, and therefore advie none to give Ear to them. But I would not have it undertood, that I deign here to direct to the Cure of Cancerated Breats of all orts, I mean thoe that are running and ulcerate, which require a skilful Surgeon's attendance and care; but only thoe that are Swell'd and Tumefy'd, as well uch as are continually, or only intermittingly painful, and whether proceeding from Blows, Falls, Strokes, ill Habits of Body, Tumours from Milk, hardnees of the Breats,
by Impothumes after Lyings-in, &c. which oftentimes by ill management, and preing and handling, turn to Cancers; I ay from what ever caue they proceed from, o they be whole and taken in time, may be cur'd by proper Applications; and if they be broken or ulcerated, to prevent its increae, and remove the hardnes and welling about it; a Medicine or two may be directed, that will (if any thing will) not fail of proving uccesful: But as I aid before, every well'd Breat being not always Cancerous, it may be neceary in two or three Words more to explain which hard or painful Breats can jutly be aid to be Cancerous, and which not o.

A Cancer in the Breat at its firt appearance looks like a mall round welling, more or les deep in the Glandulous Subtance of the Part, with little or no Pain; and when the hardnes increaes, the Pain becomes harp, and its oberv'd to be uneven, and as the welling increaes, it becomes of a livid, or blueih, or blackih Colour, the Nipples at the ame time often inking in, round about which alo there aries hard, uneven, heavy Protuberances, or little Swellings, which, as they grow big, do at lat pierce the Skin, and dicover the Cancerous Mas, from whence an Ulceration proceeds in its Subtance; the running Humour of which is reddih, the edges of the Sore broken or ragged, the tops pungy, and when it comes to a cadaverous Smell or Stench, it hews the utmot tate of a Cancer in the Breat, which will not yield for Cure to the bet Remedies in Practice.

Now in order to compas the Cure of a Cancer, requires a good Undertanding in the nature of them, without which nothing can rightly be done; and if every hard, wel'd, tumify'd or painful Breat were known at firt whether Cancerous or not, many ucceeding michiefs might be prevented; but it is o common a thing for almot every Practitioner, and every tatling Goip, preently to declare upon ight of a hard or well'd Breat, that it is Cancerous, and accordingly make Applications to it as uch, that carce one Breat in twenty they look upon or manage, but is made

the Liniment, which he had not us'd above a Week, but the Pain much abated, and Swelling began to abate, and he continued it contantly Night and Morning, and in about Two Months time, was at well as ever he was in her Life.

A Gentlewoman, a particular Friend of mine, upon a Lying-in had a ore Breat, which, altho' broke, continued hard and ometimes painful, at length is turn'd to a Gleety Humour, running out at a place near the Nipple like a Fitula, the Humour that run being ometimes yellow, and ometimes of other Colours; and ometimes thick, at other times thin, ometimes it did not run at all, at other times burt our again, till continuing hard, tender and omething painful, which put her in fear of a Cancer, and indeed did omething reemble a Fitulous Cancer; but notwithtanding, upon bathing all the Swelling with the Liniment before poken of, he in about Sixteen Weeks got cur'd of it, and is now perfectly well, tho' it be Four Years ince it was perform'd, only at times ome of the Englih Pills before-mentioned, were given her inwardly to purge a little, which are mot proper, when Humours abound, and the Body be gros, or foul, to purge now and then, in order to the quicker and more certain amendment.

A Gentlewoman by a punch upon her Breat by a Man's ruhing by her in the Street, had uch a Pain, throbbing, and at length Inflamation and Swelling, that he was told it was a Cancer, and had divers things of divers Perons for Cure, but all to no purpoe, rather aggravating than abating the Symptoms. div.head: THE Suffumigating Powder For Vapours or Hyterick Fits in Women, and Hypochondriack Melancholly or Flatus in Men, and all other Fits and Ditempers of the Nerves in general.
div.p: HAD I not more than ordinary Reaon and Experience for many Years of being acquainted with thoe Dieaes, and conequently of their Cure, I hould not take upon me to be o abolute as you will find me to be in the Matter; but they being Dieaes which do very frequently deceive numbers of Perons that are afflicted therewith, o as that they know not what they aile; I hall for their akes and benefits, before I come to treat of the aboveaid Medicine for the Cure, decribe the Symptoms and Caues thereof, and begin firt with the Vapours.

Firt then, the Vapours, otherwie called Hyterick Fits, or Fits of the Mother, is a Dieae which more generally afflicts Humane Kind than any other whatoever, and Proteus like, transforms it elf into the Shape and Repreentation of almot all Ditempers, thoe who are troubled therewith, generally perceiving them approach in the following manner: Firt, they feel a heavines upon their Breat, a grumbling in their Belly, they belch up, and ometimes Vomit owr, harp, inipid, or bitter Humour; they have a difficulty in breathing, and think they feel omething come up into their Throat, which is ready to choak them, they
truggle, cry out, make odd and inarticulate Sounds or Mutterings, they perceive a Swimming in their Heads, a Dimnes come over their Eyes, they turn Pale, are carce able to tand, their Pule is weak, they hut their Eyes, cry, hriek out, groan, foam at the Mouth, and remain Seneles for ome time, afterwards by little and little their Pule returns, their Face regains its natural colour, their Body grows hot, as before, they open their Eyes, and by degrees come to themelves.

Some moreover, have their Bellies well'd and tretched like a Drum, their Hypochondria's ditended, and they fancy they feel omewhat within them rowl from place to place, which the Ancients imagin'd to be the Womb changing from place to place, whereas the Ligaments which tye it down render that impoible; beides that, Men are alo afflicted with this Symptom as well as Women; their Pule is almot imperceptible, they feel a violent Cold run up their Backs, which afterwards trikes through their whole Body, their Head-achs, and ometimes there enues a Palpitation of the Heart and a fainting away; there are many, who when thee accidents are over, come quietly to themelves by degrees, and in others when the violent cold is ended a no les violent Heat ucceeds, which cats them again into many of the former accidents, as Palpitation of the Heart, Head-achs, Giddines, difficulty in Breathing; and into ome new ones, as Fluhings of the Face, Raving, Convulions, foaming at the Mouth, violent beating of the Mucles and Arteries, and a tingling Senation in the Thighs, which are Paralitick, during the cold Fit; nay, ometimes the Palie will continue in the hot Fit too, ometimes the cold with which the Fit begins is hardly perceptible, and then the Patient has no remarkable accidents whilt the cold lats; but when the hot Fit comes on, it is accompanied with everal of the above-numbred accidents, but the Pule beats higher and quicker than in the foregoing tate, and if no coldnes was to be perceived at all before the hot Fit, then many of the ame accidents will happen, but only
in a more violent degree, and till more frequent and beats higher.

Sometimes the Patients in this Ditemper fall into uch violent Fits of Struggling, that they can hardly be held; they mutter odd and inarticulate Sounds, grate their Teeth, foam at their Mouths, and trike their Breats; others uffer much violent, and long continued Contractions of the Diaphragm and Int â€¢â€¢
cotal Mucles, that their Breat and lower Belly remain elevated for a long time together, o that they cannot draw their Breath all that while; nay, ome have lain for three whole days without the leat ign of breathing perceivable by thoe that were about them.
One complains of a violent Pain on the top of her Head, which is frequently accompanied with Vomiting.
Another is troubled with a Pain under her Heart, and a reaching to Vomit, or Vomits a mixture of Porraceous and Cholerick Humours, and it ends in a Jaundice.

A third lyes with her Jaws pres'd together with all the violence imaginable, and her Notrils drawn together o cloe that he is in danger of being uffocated, and ometimes remains for a coniderable while as if he were dead.
A fourth upon the mell of Civit, Musk, Ambergreae, or any uch weet Scent, hall fall into Fits.
A fifth hall be moleted with them upon any Anger, Paion or Diturbance of Mind, which is immediately followed with great quantity of pale Urine.

A ixth is very thoughtful, bluhes or grows pale on a udden, has a deprav'd Appetite, ometimes to craving, at other times to loathing all orts of uual Meats, and is pleaed only with the eating of aburd things, as Chalk, Charcole, &c.
A eventh will on a udden fall into extravagant Fits of Crying or Laughing, without being provok'd by any external Caue.

Beides all thee, everal other accidents happen to People troubled with this Dieae, as a Pain in the Bladder and Kidneys, like that of the Stone and Gravel, violent Cholicks, Swellings in the Jaws, Shoulders, Legs, Hands or Thighs, which yield not to the Finger that prees, nor retain any Mark; Pain in the Back, which all feel more or les, as alo in everal Parts of the Body o violent, that the Place affected cannot endure touching for a long while afterwards; they breath hort and with Pain, yawn and tretch, their Sleep is diturb'd, and their Dreams are frightful, their Eyes are fixt and taring, ometimes they remember what happen'd in their Fit, ometimes they do not, they cough without intermiion, pit in vat quantities for everal Weeks, as if they were in a Salivation, with many other accidents too tedious to enumerate.

Latly, we oberve that thoe who have labour'd long under this Ditempe are oppres'd with a dreadful Anguih of Mind, and a deep Melancholly, always reflecting on what can perplex, terrifie and diorder them mot, o that at leat they think their Recovery impoible, and are very angry with thoe that pretend there is any hopes of it; the leat contradiction to their will, cat them into violent Paions; they are fickle, wavering and uncontant, now reolving on one thing, and immediately changing to omething ele, which they as preently quit, and by indulging their Ditemper, decline all orts of Diverions.

But Note, that all thee accidents do not happen to every one that has Vapours, or Hyterick Fits, but ome to one ome to another: This Peron hall be moleted with a great many, that with but a few of thoe Symptoms, and it uffices, that any two or three of them return by intervals, to have them term'd Vapours.

It is alo oberv'd, that this Ditemper comes by Fits, and has its intervals like an Ague, tho' the return be not exactly Periodical like it, and that in every Paroxim the ame accidents happen as did in the precedent, provided the Patient committed no exces in the interval.

Thus much for the Symptoms, the next thing to be conider'd, is the Caue of this Dieae, which is neceary to be taken notice of, the better to be avoided as much as is poible, and which ome aign to this, others to that, and others different to both, which, tho' all plauible Notions, fall hort of the real caue, wanting Reaon back'd by Experience and Matter of Fact to upport them; but forbearing to enumerate their everal imaginary Notions, I hall in hort, content my elf to hew the true and only Caues thereof, which are Crudities and Indigetions of the Stomach, nothing ele being to be found within the Stomach and the Guts capable of producing thoe Symptoms, unles it be the Aliments we take, but thee we know when well concocted and digeted, are o far from producing any ill effects upon Humane Bodies, that they alone utain and preerve them in a capacity of exerciing their Natural and Animal Functions: However, if they by any vitious Concoction turn into Crudities and Indigetions, then their laudable Qualities are chang'd into quite oppoite ones, and they produce the many Accidents and Symptoms of this Ditemper; for when by the vitious qualification of the Ferment of the Stomach, the Aliments are not well digeted, they turn into Crudities, thee Crudities by little and little gather together in the wrinkles and olds of the Stomach and Guts, where they lye for ome time without much enible motion or fermentation within themelves, till at lat by the Circumjacent Parts, their groer Salts are divided and put into motion, which Fermentation is augmented by the various Juices that flow into the Guts, from the many Glands which are placed in the lower Belly, and by this means they are diolv'd and liquify'd as to enter by the Milky Veins into the Blood, where they produce all the accidents of this Ditemper, which the only way to prevent in all Perons, and epecially in uch where the Vapours are fear'd, is to cleane the Stomach and Bowels of the Saburra which lies in them; and that frequently, viz. once in a Month, oftner or eldomer, as there may be occaion, with ome proper, gentle, abterive Vomit or Purge,
than which nothing can exceed the famous Englih Pills aforegoing, taking them as you ee occaion; thus much for the Symptoms, Caues, and Prevention of the Dieae.

But perfectly to cure the Vapours or Hyterick Fits, or Fits of the Mother, in uch that are o unhappily afflicted, the Caue mut be eradicated, and the Blood retored to its Natural Contitution, without which the effect can never ceae, and that the common Medicines in Practice are not capable of performing it, is daily een by the few (if any) that are cured therewith, they only being ufficient, and ometimes not that, to appeae the Symptom â€¢ and palliate the Dieae; but uch is the prevalency of the aforeaid Englih Pills and this Suffumigation, that they immediately trike at the Root of the Dieae, and never leave (if reiterated) till the whole Oeconomy of the Body is chang'd, which will oon be perceiv'd by the <> , or not return of the uual Symptoms, or Paroxims, the manner of taking which Pills, with obervations to be heeded as to Diet, &c. is at large before et forth, with which and this Suffumigation (they oberving Rules as to Diet, &c.) numbers of Hyterick Perons have been cured, when they have lain ome Months in violent Ravings, and other Symptoms, almot uppos'd irretrievable.

Secondly, of Hypochondriack Melancholly, or Flatus in Men, which is a ort of Cachexie that frequently reigns in our Northern Climates, whoe Symptoms appearing motly in the Hypochondria, is term'd the Hypochondriack Dieae, and when its Symptoms are very fierce and exalted, 'tis entitule the Scurvy, a Name given it by the Saxons in Nor â€¢â€¢
Germany, who are mot liable to it; the better part of Authors upon this Subject being amus'd with its Symptoms and Effects, have vainly fancy'd to etablih its Original Seat in everal Bowels that are only accidentally concern'd; but if they trac'd it to its tate of Infancy and firt beginning, they mut have pitch'd upon the Stomach for the Place of its Nativity, and upon the Acid vicous Cruditie, that a faulty digetion occaion for its Caues.

For our further atisfaction in this matter, we hall briefly run over its Symptoms, and if we find that they owe their Being to an Acid Crudity in the Stomach, hall reckon that we have made our point good. In the firt place then, the Appetite is over-keen in Hypochondriack Perons, their Digetion being weak, and follow'd by Convulive or weighty Pains in the Stomach, belching Wind and Noie, epecially in the left ide of the Belly, where the Gut-Colon is traitned; they are always Cotive, and Laxatives operate better in them than Purgatives; if an Artificial or Natural Vomiting happen, they throw up Acid Matter, which tupfiies, or ets the Teeth on edge, and which will corrode a Copper Veel o as to render it ruty. After Eating, they are oft-times eiz'd with a gnawing Pain in the Stomach, reaching along the Back from the lower part to the Neck of the Gullet (which ome mical Nephritick Pains) as alo with udden fluhings in the Face, wringing Pains in the Guts, palpitation of the Heart, perturbation of Mind, and a difficulty of breathing, occaion'd either by vicous Crudities ditending the Stomach or Convulions of the Midriff, and Mucles of the Breat, or Wind in the Abdomen, hindring the decent of the Midriff; while their Stomach is empty, they are apt to be giddy and dull, they are liable to periodical Exaperations; frequently they are enible (as it were) of Fumes riing up from the Belly, and the Paroxim reembles an Hyterical Fit, in the Paroxim the colour and conitence of their Urine is incontant, but when 'tis over, returns to a Natural order. Thee are the Symptoms of Hypochondriack Peron, but all of them are rarely to be een in one Peron, the mot certain Symptoms that always attend, are Gripings and Wind in the Guts, a weak Stomach, Cotivenes, and Perturbation of the Head.

The Symptoms being thus premis'd, we come now to enquire after the Caue of this Dieae, the firt and original of which is a vicious Acid in the Stomach enlarging the Appetite, but unfit for Digetion, hence enues an Acid Crudity in the firt Paages, which depraves the crais of the Blood, prevents the due eparation
of volatil Spirits, upon which the Lymph becomes Acid, and the Bile inactive.

Thee are the Sources of all the preceding Symptoms, ince Wind, Noie, Griping of the Guts and Cotivenes are the natural reult of a vicious Acid in the firt Paages, as fluhings in the Face arie from its effervecence with the Bile, the Convulions of the nervous Membranes in everal Parts of the Body are the effect of its Iritation; its Crudity impairs the due Fermentation of the Blood, and caues a palpitation of the Heart, and difficulty of Breathing; it depraves the Nutritious Juice of the Bowels which ettles into hard Swellings, and occaions a degeneracy and auterity in the Spirits; hence Fear, Melancholly, irregular Thoughts and uncouth emotions enue.

The remote Caues that promote Crudities are Acid Liquors or Salt Victuals, or uch as are dried in the Smoak, ince both partake of the Acid Spirit of Salt or Soot; alo want of motion to promote digetion, and the peedy aimilation of the Chyle; likewie Nocturnal Study and over thoughtfulnes and care, exhaut the Spirits, impoverih the Blood, and render the Lymph acid; Thus much for the Symptoms and Caue of this Dieae.

Now as to the Cure, its conits in correcting and evacuating the Crudities of the firt Paages, fortifying the Stomach, retrieving the due crais of the Blood, and retoring all wonted Evacuations to their former coure, in order to compas which ends, let the following Rules be heedfully minded.

1t, That a Doe of the Englih Pills aforementioned be taken o often as you find occaion, with a careful regular Diet, and uing a moderate quantity of true natural red Wine mix'd with Water intead of Maltdrinks, which, with the ue of the Suffumigating Powder I hall by and by give directions about, never fails etting them to rights, as numbers in very deplorable conditions have happily experienced.

2dly, Their way of living both in the Vapours and Hypochondriack Melancholly, as to Dyet, ought to conit chiefly of cooling refrehing Nourihments, Food of
good Juyce, eating Water-gruel, Barley and Rice-Broths, Rice-milk, boil'd and roat Veal and Mutton, Veal or Chicken-Broths not made o trong as uually, eating no Salt or piced Meats.

3dly, They mut leep not too much, neither indulge Melancholly or thoughtfulnes, but be cheerful and ue diverions, keeping in company that is mirthful and talkative, ride and take the freh Air; which, with the variety of different Company and Objects which they ee, concur to pleaure the Mind and remove all anxious Thoughts, and thereby contribute much towards the Cure.

And for all Dieaes of the Nerves, Fits of all orts, whether Convulions, Falling Sicknes, Apoplexies, Lethargies, Palies or other Diorders of the Animal Spirits and Brain, Spams, Tremblings, Contractions, Relaxations of the Limbs, Numbnes, Coldnes, or the like, a Doe now and then of the aforeaid Englih Pills, and uing the Suffumigating Powder, as I hall preently direct, nothing will be found more efficacious, epecially if the contracted or relaxed Limbs be anointed every Night with Oil of Amber, and the following Diet-drink be made and drank contantly of, which is alo excellent in Vapours and Melancholly.

Take Mutard Seeds, 4 Ounces buied, Hore-radih Roots two Ounces, Scurvy-gras two Handfuls, Aaron Roots half an Ounce, Bryony Roots two Ounces, boil all in a Gallon of Spring Water till a Quart be boil'd away, then train it, and drink half a Pint three times a day.

Ue the Suffumigating Powder thus, put a Paper of it upon ome live Coals in a Chaing-dih or ome uch a thing, and put in under a Chair with a Hole in it, clapping a Funnel upon the Coals, o that the Smoak will go through the Funnel, and the Patient itting upon the Chair bare, will receive it up the Fundament, which mut be o done every Night going to Bed, or once in 2 or 3 Nights, according as there is occaion, whereby in Fits, Vapours, &c. there is intant Relief. ration, a hort hint of the Blood, its changes A nalitically prov'd, and the Rationale of the Gout, its Nature and Caues from thence explicately deduc'd.

The Blood of Man is made up of a mixture of divers Principles, to wit, a Bitter, a Sweet, a Salt, an Acid, &c. the mixture and temperaments of which, while mutual, preerves the Body in a tate of Health, and conequently creates no trouble or uneaines: But when any one of thee Principles is divided or eperated from the ret, and exits by it elf, then the effects plainly hew what great Trouble, Perplexity, and Pain it creates in the Body.

Now nothing more conduces to the eparation of thoe Homogene Principles of of the Blood, than a fault in either ome, or all of the ix Non-naturals, as Air; Meat and Drink; Sleep and want of Sleep; the Motion and Ret of the Body; the retaining and dicharging of the Excrements; and the Paions of the Mind; but the chief error is in Meat and Drink, in pampering the Body with more plenty than is needful; by which means the Particles of the Blood are not o exactly mix'd with the ret of the Mas, but are blended and confounded, o as to become Heterogeneous (the Principles jarring one with another) occaioning uch a perturbation and preternatural Fermentation, as evidently hew Sanguification to be vitiated, and the whoe Mas corrupted, thereby forcing the Sharp and Foreign Juices, together with part of the Serum, by what way it finds; as for intance, if they get into the Guts, they are evacuated by a watery Looenes; if into the Kidneys, by plenty of Urine; if into the habit of the Body, by the Pores of the Skin; but if they fall upon the Joynts, they pierce into the innermost receles and intertices of
the Nervous Parts, and caue the Gout; and as the Salt in the Serum is the thicker or thinner, it much alters its Nature; o that when the Extremities of the Mucles, Tendons, Ligaments, Fibres, and other Nervous parts of the Joynts are twitched by them, more or les Pain, Heat and Violence are occaion'd, and it proves to be a Fit of a longer or horter duration.

This Serum, tho' it be thin and harp, is at firt but very mall, occaioning but little Pain; but that little Pain, if the Caue of it be timely remov'd, grows greater at every Fit, and the more violent the Pain is, greater tore of Serum abounds, and very often a flood of other Humours is carried along with it; which caues that Swelling, Heat, Throbbing and Uneaines every one afflicted with it feels, which leaves not the Patient till the Humour is pent, at which time that Fit of the Gout is at end.

I aid before that a fault in ome of the ix Non-Naturals nam'd, was the caue of the Gout, and that pampering the Body with plenty, was the Chief, I mean thereby Gluttony and Drunkennes, epecially upon eating uch Meats as are tor'd with harp Matter, not to be ufficiently eparated or dicharg'd, or that can be eaily mix'd or temper'd with the other Juices of our Bodies; as alo drinking too plentifully of Wines which have much Tartar in them: For not only that Tartar, but the Spiritous part breeds the Gout; which Spirit conits of an Oil, an Acid and a Volatile Salt, in which the trength of Wine conits. Yet as Exces therein hurts, o Temperance preerves the Health: For thoe Wines which mot abound with Tartar, are much more homogene to our Bodies, than other Wines that have little Tartar in them, and hould be made choice of; and are the bet with Moderation for all Contitutions and Temperaments, and the Red of all orts, is far more preferrable than the White.

And not only is it manifet that the Gout is bred by Gluttony and Drunkennes, but alo other innumerable inconveniencies are caus'd thereby, for by that means the Appetite is detroy'd, the Digetions vitiated, &c. the conequences of which every one may eaily conider,
and time, (if not prevented) will mot certainly and fatally determine: For a good Appetite and perfect Digetions, are o indipenably neceary to the upport and preervation of Humane Life, that we can no more well ubit without the one, than we can long without the other; the one indicates Dieaes preent, the other threatens Dieaes to come, and frequently brings the whole Humane Oeconomy into diorder and confuion: For when there is a depravitty of the Primae Viae, the Chyle into which the Food is converted in the Stomach, is deprav'd alo; and according as is the Chyle, o mut the Blood of neceity be, whether it be good or whether it be bad, and according to which the Body uffers more or les.

And as ome forts of Meats and Drinks, and Intemperance therein are hurtful, o alo the Eating of Suppers are more than ordinary pernicious, for they pervert the functions of the Body, and injure the mind; and then at thoe Seaons to eat too plentifully, contributes much more to the poiling of the Blood, as every one that has for any time followed the Practice has oberv'd; few things being more detrimental and ruinous to the Health, as all Phyicians allow; and as in Schola Salerni it is well noted, where it is aid,

q.l: Ex magna Coena Stomacho fit maxima Paena,
Ut is nocte levis, it tibi Coena brevis.
Great Suppers put the Stomach to great pain,
Sup lightly, if good Ret you mean to gain.

div.p: Alo over hard Study, epecially in the Night time, which in this Cae is the wort, and afflicting Cares, hinders Sanguification and breed the Gout; o that the harp part in the Aliment receiv'd, is either not well mix'd, or not well eparated, and therefore cannot be well dicharged. Likewie Anger and Paion very much injure: For,

q.l: Exhiler at Tritres, iratos, placat, amantes,
Ne fuit amentes, mens laeta, requires, &c.
'Tis Mirth that Nureth Life and Blood,
Far more than Wine, or Ret or Food.

div.p: Alo immoderate and uneaonable Venery conduces not a little; for it weakens the Strength, hurts the Brain, extinguihes Radical Moiture, and hatens old Age and Death; the Sperm, or Seed of Generation, being the only Comfort of Nature, which willfully hed or lot, injures a Man more than the los of forty times that quanty of Blood; wherefore Virgil well ays,

q.l: Nulla Magis animi vires Indutria firmat,
Quam Venerem & caeci timulos avertere amoris.
Much Venery caue great Ills to Mind and Blood,
Exhauts the Stock, unfits Man for's Wife's good,
When moderately us'd, holds long, and helps as Food.

div.p: Levinus Lemnius likewie ays, if a Man intends to Live Long and happy during the Life he leads, he hould, Veci citra aturitatem, non refugere laborem, vitale emen conervare.
That is, make light Meals, ue Exercie, and preerve his Seed, which is the vital and principal Part of Life, and certainly nothing more auredly breeds the Gout than immmoderate Venery.
Thus the Caues of the Gout being ufficiently explicated, I hall next give a definition of it, its Nature and Remedy.

The Gout then is a mot intene, enible Pain of the Tendonous Membranous Parts about the Joints, caued by a Serous, Pungent and exceeding harp Humour, forced uddenly out of the Veels from an inward dipeition,
and led thither by the intertices of the Nervous Parts.

The ign of its coming, or being preent, are ometimes wandring Pains, epecially in the Joynts of the Feet or Hands: That it is at hand, is hewn by a tretching, yawning, painful wearines; Catarrhs, Pains in the Limbs and Joints, and ometimes a heavines in the Head, a kind of Feverih heat, a pricking Pain in the Joints, cauing tarting, with inability to move; and after that comes a Swelling, uually red, attended with Watching, los of Strength, tiffnes of the Parts, and everal other complaints, not alike to all at all times, yet is what Gouty People well know, and are more acquainted with than is conitent with their Eae.

The way to remedy this untoward Evil, is firt to remove the Caue, that is, that which aggravates the Paroxim; and econdly to preerve the Patient from the return of a Fit, or at leatwie to render it when it comes, more eay, and not o intollerable as we frequently find it to be; for when it has once feiz'd a Man, it will (if not prevented by proper Medicines) return again at certain eaons and ditances of Time, as the Gouty Matter in the Blood is a freh increas'd, gather'd and led down to the Joints, which ditances are longer or horter, and the Paroxims greater or leer, according as the Patient live Regular or Irregular, and according as is the trength or weaknes of his Contitution; for if it be weak or broke, or the Patient in Mala Stamina Vitae, it occaions its coming oftener, pains him worer, and holds him longer than if the ame Contitution was tronger, and the Patient in Bona Stamina Vitae; and alo acccording as he takes proper Medicines to evacuate that Humour, by leading it away by the proper Paages.

I know ome Phyician's Doctrine is to let Nature take her free Coure, adviing their Patients to bear under the burden of that intolerable Miery as well as they can. Indeed, in the Knotted Gout the Advice may hold good, for there, no Cure can be
expected, according to that known ancient, but true Axiom, Solvere nodoam necit Medicina Podagram.
Againt the knotted Gout no Medicine can prevail.

But even there a Cure, as to the Fit, may be obtain'd, as well as in other Fits of the Gout; for the longer a Patient lies under its everity the more the Humours of the Body flow down, which keeps the Part more lax and weaker, and the Patient longer confin'd, which may be prevented; and when a Remedy to Eae, by carrying thoe Humours away by Urine and Perpiration, which would crowd down upon thoe weakned Joints, may o eaily be had; for a Patient to reject it, and not to hearken to uch a Remedy, hews his willingnes to retain his Miery, and is like uffering an Ague to hake him for a Year, or ome certain time, before he'll prevail'd with to take Medicines to cure it.

But the common aying among all being, That there's no Cure for the Gout, makes every one's Propoals look Prepoterous, even where there is but the bare mentioning of doing it: But if any thing I ay be found out that manifetly carries off the Gouty Caue by Urine and Perpiration, which would otherwie flow down to the Joints, o that the Patient is av'd from the Pain, I fee not why any hould be offended, or that a Gouty Patient would rather bear his Pain than be o incredulous, as not to make experiment of it, when the Nature of the Medicine is uch, and the Operation o afe, that every one that has any knowledge of things, mut allow that it cannot poible be hurtful, for that no Evacuation is more to advantage than by Urine and Peripiration, and that with uch a Medicine as makes a regular eparation by the trainers, by firt carrying them away moothly and freely throughly the Uteters, which always of neceity would have been thrown upon the Joints and conequently caue a Fit, proper Dieureticks being what all Phyicians allow to be the mot effectual Evacuations to divet the Blood of
thoe peccant Salts, which, if not remov'd, would prove injurious to the Patient.

And to do this, nothing is more prevalent than the Englih Pills aforemention'd, whoe admirable Virtues are uch, that thoe who never try'd them, will carce believe; who yet after taking them, will to every one of their Friends recommend them. Therefore to ay more would be needles; nothing being o like to convince a Man of their Efficacy, as making tryal, which is the trut Tet; and by whoe Succes the Reputation both of the Medicine and the Author deires to depend, and by which he is content either to tand or to fall.

The Pills are taken as directed in the Account before given of them, and that oftener or eldomer, as there may be occaion. And to give preent Eae and remove wholly the Pain, the Cataplam is to be apply'd warm to the Part every Night and Morning, till the Pain is quite gone, which will oon be.

The Price of the Ingredients is Five Shillings the Gallipot, which are to be boiled with fix Ounces of Crumbs of White Bread and a Pint of Milk, to the conitence of a Cataplam, or Poultice, which is to be pread upon Linnen Cloath, as thick as two Crown Pieces put together, and applyed I ay as warm as can well be borne to the Gouty Part, renewing it very Night and Morning. The Pot of Ingredients are to be had only at the Place aforementioned.

It infallibly and expeditiouly cures Weaknees of the Back in both Sexes, and all Pains of the Back whatoever, whether occaioned from Bruies, Falls, Wrenches, Strains by lifting, carrying, or by Sicknes and Weaknes, or from Womens Micarriages, Lyingsin, Frights, Grief, or the like. It effectually prevents Micarriages, tho' you have micarried never o many times; and this it does by trengthening and nourihing the Womb and weak Foetus therein; for it corrects the Blood and Humours that affords Nourihment, and if the Symptoms or danger at any time of Micarrying appears, the taking immediately of this Electuary, certainly ecures you, if not too far let alone before you begin.

It wonderfully corrects and alters the heat, thinnes and harpnes of the Blood, which occaions immoderate or over-flowing of the Coures of Nature, by which many are reduc'd to a very low and dangerous condition, and that more epecially in Elderly Women, upon whom, they ought naturally to top, which if neglected, and not timely remedied, will occaion Bearings down, bring the Whites, and other weaknees and oulnes of the Womb, introducing in time Ulcers, Cancers, &c. for prevention of which, the Electuary is a mot admirable Remedy, only the better to correct and thoroughly to evacuate the vitious Humours, 'twill be neceary that you Purge twice or thrice in the time of taking it with our Englih Pills aforegoing

Such Women therefore that have regard to their own welfare, will have recoure to this Electuary at uch time as the Coures of Nature are about to leave them, and not as many do, take little or no care concerning it, notwithtanding Nature is always o kind to let them know, that he wants the help of Art at that Juncture, by their Coures dodging them, and their flowing but poorly, and ometimes not at all, ebbing and flowing untimely and irregular, ometimes paler and thinner, at other times in maller quantity and foul, which is warning ufficient, that he tands in need of help, and that they ought at that time to be ettled and dipoed after a particular manner, and not be neglected as many Women to their Sorrow have done, who for want of uch care, are now complaining of either Vapour, Fluhings all over the Body, the Whites in abundance, purines at Stomach, los of Appetite, Cholicks, Faintings, or other the like Weaknees and Indipoitions, which if not timely remedied, brings Ulcers or Cancers in the Womb, Dropies, Conumptions or other fatal Ditempers; but Women that are wife will in time prevent thoe inconveniencies, by making ue of this Electuary, which will be of unpeakable advantage; who in the time of taking it (if Plethorick or full of Blood and not much reduc'd) mut once be let Blood, and purge with our Englih Pills aforegoing, once, jut before you begin with the Electuary, and twice or thrice more in the time that your are taking it, by which means they will auredly be preerved and ecured from thoe Dangers.

Alo for uch Women that are afflicted with a Flux of their Coures and the Whites together, as numbers of them are, and reduc'd extreamly low with the ame, this Electuary is a Remedy that cannot be equall'd; only for correction of Humours and the better to cleane

And as this Electuary has cured many in the aforegoing Ditempers, o likewie has it perfectly cured everal Children and others of riper Years of incontinency of Urine, Piing in Bed, and the Diabetes, and that after the continuance of the Ditemper for everal Years, and when multitudes of Medicines have been ued to no purpoe; and has alo cured everal Children and others of the falling down of the Fundament and Ruptures where the Rim or Peritonaeum has not been broken, it being a Medicine which o admirably and potently trengthens the inward Parts, as never to fail, tho' ometimes I have been oblig'd for the better facilitating and making lating the Cure, o as that the Ditemper may never return again) to exhibit our Englih Pills (o often mentioned) for correcting of the Humours, adminitring them in proportion to the Age and Strength of the Patient.
