It is a Cordial corroborating, and trengthning Medic â€¢ ne, makes not the Stomach ick or uneaie, unles it be very weak or oul, nor caues the leat diorder whatoever, but is o very afe and harmles, that you may go abroad in the taking, (if able) and that without any other care or obervation than what is uual; only let your Motion and Exercie be gentle, the quieter and tiller you keep, the better.

div.head: OF THE CAUSES OF THE FISTULA in Ano: OR, The Fundament, With its certain Cure by an Injection, without Cutting or Burning, &c.
div.p:
THE Caues of Fitula's proceed chiefly from Plegmons and Hemorrhoids, or Piles, broken or ill cur'd, or that are not cur'd in a long time; as alo from the application of Hore-leeches to the Pile, which are commonly done, and not well cur'd, they leaving ome Venemous Matter behind them, which in time creates a malignant or corroive Indipoition, that in time makes a Sinus, or Hollownes, becoming, if neglected, Callous; alo Bruies or Hurts on thoe Parts caue Swellings and Fitula's. I ay often thoe are the caues of Fitula's in the Fundament; but there is another Caue not much taken notice of, or at leat wie is what few People care to own, and that is, proceeding from, an ill cur'd Clap, which is more frequently the caue of Fitula's than any other, I having oberv'd
that where one Fitula is occaion'd by any other means, ten proceeds from that, tho' it may be o many Years after, as to give reaons to the contrary, yet is certainly o; epecially if the Patient had been for Cure of that Clap in the Hands of ome Pretender, or was too hatily cur'd, which is what now adays, tho' very wrongful to the Patient, mot endeavour to be valu'd upon, when a true Cure is gradatium, and ought to be no more hudled up, than it hould be prolong'd, as all true Artits in uch Cures well know.

The Fitula generally comes on gradually, its Matter paing at firt between the Tunicles of the Intetinum Rectum, and is of a thin gleety Nature, which makes its way out near the verge of the Fundament, through as it were at firt of a mall Pin-hole, and is perceiv'd by its taining the Shirt or Shift of the Patient without any Pain, and is thought (tho' mitakenly) to be rather a kind of Sweating Moiture than a real Fitulous Matter.

But in time, if not remedied, this Humour occaions an itching, and ubjects the Patient to excoriation or galling of the Part by it continual moitnes and harpnes of the Humour, which alo in longer time caues everal kinds of mall Pimples or Putles to break out; and ometimes Rhagades, Fiurae or Chops, which at length caues the Sinus to pread outwards, and the extremity of the Orifice to grow hard, callous and o contracted, as not to admit the paing in of a mall Probe.

Sometimes thoe Fitula's pas deep among the Intertitia of the Mucles, according to the harp Matter can make its way; ometimes they penetrate through the Intetinum Rectum to the very neck of the Bladder, may, ometimes into the Pelvis, or amongt the Muculi Glut â€¢ i and other Parts, being then very painful, and ends forth a purulent anious Matter, harp, ugly and tinking, and that in greater or les quantity, as the hollownes reaches, which in time grows very Callcus, and makes its twiting and twining like a Coney Burvow, which are the very wort ort of Fitula's.

There are two orts of Fitula's in Ano, one pierces through the Intetinum Rectum, or Gut, into the Fundament, and the other not, and both of them are either hallow or deep, which you may eaily come to find out. If it paes into the Fundament, you will, upon breaking Wind, find part of it make its way through the Sinus of the Fitula; alo if the Excrements appear mingled with the Quittour of the Fitula, or if the Quittour that comes from the outer Orifice of the Fitula mells like the Excrements, it is a certain ign it paes into the Fundament. If by injecting any Liquor at the outer Orifice of the Fitula, part of it paes through into the Fundament, or if by paing a pliable Probe into the outer Orifice of the Fitula, you can feel the end of the Probe bare to your Finger put into the Fundament, they are infallible igns the Fitula goes into the Fundament.

As for the Preages or Prognoticks of Fitula's, it is allow'd by all that they are not eay of Cure; for the Parts being depending, and as it were the Sink of the Body, o great plenty of Humours and Impurities, and much uperfluous Moiture lows naturally down, and always hinders the Cure.

The Curative part of Fitula's, Authors tell us, depend on five means, viz. Diet, internal Medicaments, Inciion, Deligation, and Topical Applications. As for Diet and internal Medicaments, they are what is abolutely neceary, as alo ome Topical means; but for Inciion or Cutting, or applying Cauticks or Corroives, o frequently now adays advis'd, and almot as frequently perform'd (but with what Succes the Patients themelves are bet able to relate) I by no means agree to, unles in ome particular Caes, where the Patients Life is in danger, and where no other means whatoever will avail. Such I ay, for to ave Life, cutting or applying Cauticks &c. are and ought to be us'd, as alo in ome uperficial Fitula's that run upwards by the Intetinum Rectum; but to make Inciien in all promicuouly, has been the ruine of many, and the one cutting, which the Patient was told would be ufficient for Cure, has occaioned more Sinus's by the Inflamation
and Pain, and the f â€¢ uxion of Humours thereby upon thoe depending Parts, o that cutting again and again has been done, to the utter poiling of the Patient, cauing the Fitula to be inveterate, to run much, to the extenuating the Body, decaying the Strength, whence los or debilitation of Stomach enues, and at length Faintnes, cold Sweats, &c. which brings the Fitula and whole Body into uch a State, as that all hopes of Cure are pat, epecially if the Fitula was deep, or penetrated beyond the Muculi Ani, for by cutting uch, if they are cur'd, the Patients will carcely ever retain their Excrements but with great difficulty, if no wore accidents happen; and if they reach beyond the Sphincter, the retention of the excrements will be impoible, o that great care ought to be taken, and a Skilful Surgeon advis'd with, before the Patient ubmits to be cut at all.

It is allow'd by all, that Fitula's that are very Sinous, and have been of long tanding, are dangerous and of difficult Cure, epecially if they dicharge a large quantity of Pus, and lie o far ditant, as that there is no coming at the bottom, but the nearer they are to the Anus, the more eaie they are of Cure.

The Anus, or Fundament, is more ubject to Fitula's than any other part in the whole Body, becaue the great quantity of Fat, with which the Intetinum Rectum is loaded, and the Evacuation of the Excrements (this being the common Sink where all the filth of the Body is brought down to be carried off) from its continual Humidity and numerous Veels, as Branches of the Hypogatrick Arteries and Veins; a Branch of the Aorta; another of the Inferior or Meenterick Artery; the Hemoirrhoidal Veins; the vat number of Lymphaticks; the Glands alo eperating a white Glairy Vicous Liquor; I ay thoe meeting there and Humours from internal Caues, whether Obtructions, Inflammations, Acees, Ulcers, Piles; or external, as Blows, Contuions, impure Embraces, Falls, Leeches ill applied, &c. which happening more or les to meet there, as being a Part more dipos'd, it is no wonder to find
Fitula's o oon form'd and o frequent as we oberve them to be.

There are ome Fitula's that are not noiome nor very troubleome or painful, and that ometimes are open and run, at other times cloe, and the Patient is dry, and thus they do for many Years without any great inconveniency, and is what is found expedient for the Health of the Patient; for thereby the Body is dicharg'd of uperfluous Humours, which otherwie might breed great diorders, and endanger the Patient's Life. I have known many People have uch Fitula's which have contributed greatly to their Health, and continued on them to the end of their Lives.

But enough has been aid as to the Nature, Caue and Conequence of this troubleome and oftentimes dangerous Indipoition. I hall now come to peakof its Cure, which is what was chiefly at firt aim'd at, and what I preume is by the Patient expected.

I have aid already that cutting is not neceary in all, and hew'd wherein it is, and is not for the Patients afety, and where it is not I hall recommend a Method, which if follow'd according to directions, will be found more beneficial than many Phyicians and Surgeons will be ready or willing to believe.

In the firt place, the Patient is gently to purge with the Englih Pills herein recommended, and to repeat them oncein a Week, oftner or eldomer as the Body is gros, or Humours abound, but not to take too large a Doe; for gentle Purging is bet; and he is alo at the ame time to make the following Dyet-drink, which he is contantly to drink of till he is perfectly well; and is this.

Take Burdock Roots 8 Ounces; Elecampane Roots 3 Ounces; Tormentil and Bitort Roots, of each an Ounce; Sanicle 2 handfuls; Germander, Ground-Ivy and Agrimony, of each 2 handfuls; Saraparilla 6 Ounces; China Roots 3 Ounces; Saaphras 3 Ounces; Guaiacum 4 Ounces; Raions of the Sun and Figs, of each 4 Ounces, Liquorih 3 Ounces; boil all in 12 Pints of Lime Water, till 2 Pints are boil'd away, then train it and drink half a Pint every Morning, and 4 or 5
in the Evening, and at Night going to Bed, a little warm'd.

Upon the ue of this Dyet-drink, and now and then, (but not too often) purging with the aforeaid Pills, and uing at the ame time the Injection into the Fitula, the Patient will find the Cure will come on; for the Purging gently carries off the Humonrs, the Dyet-drink dries up the uperfluous Moiture, and nourihes and trengthens the Body, and the Injection, which I am now going to mention, will cleane and cicatrize the Fitula, that the Patient, if he continues the Coure long enough, which he mut be ure to do, if he expects to be well (for thoe things will take up time, in ome more in ome les, according as is the Indipoition) will find it to anwer his expectation, without the pain and danger of cutting, which has ruin'd many.

The Injection for this purpoe is neither corroive or will caue pain; it is to be injected into the Fitula every Night and Morning warm with a Syringe, two Syringes full each time, which upon cating in, he will find (if the Fitula goes into the Fundament) to come ome of it out at the Fundament; but he is not to put the point of the Syringe into the Fitula too far, but jut o much in, as that the Liquor will be forc'd into the Orifice;

By this means I have cur'd everal, and mot, if not all that ue the method, will have the ame ucces; for the Injection takes away all Calloity; and yet I ay, without pain, cleanes, atringes, dries up and cicatrizes the Part, that by degrees the Fitula will cloe and heal up from end to end to the great pleaure and atisfaction of the before terrify'd Patient, who cou'd hear nothing from his Surgeon but Cutting, Cutting, which News is receiv'd by ome as unwelcome as an Old-Baily Sentence to a Criminal.
The Price of the Injection is 5s. the Bottle. To be had only at the Place before-mentioned.

div.head: Tinctura Cephalica: OR, HEAD-TINCTURE.
div.p: THE mot incomparable and appropriated Medicine that can poibly be made ue of for preventing and curing all Ditempers of the Head and Brain, as Head-achs, Megrim, Vertigo, Epilepies, Palies, Apoplexies, Lethargies, Convulions, Phrenies, Carus, Coma, trembling of the Nerves, Numbnes, los of Memory, dulnes and heavines of the Senes, Drowines, tating and melling hurt, weaknes, glimmering or dulnes of the Sight, thicknes of Hearing, noies in the Head, beating or hooting Pains, &c. which numbers of Perons are orely afflicted with, and which very often eizes uch as are over thoughtful and tudious, &c. thoe Dieaes (amongt the numbers that afflict Mankind) being generally the mot uncomfortable, lating and dangerous.

It truly and mot tupendouly repairs weak Memories, bad Eye-ight and Hearing, being inwardly taken, and outwardly made ue of, and trengthens and preerves the ame, removing dulnes, drowines and heavines from the Spirits and Senes, rendring the Intellectuals lively, quick and apprehenive, &c. being peculiarly adapted to remove all Head-dieaes, even to help uch that are craz'd, whoe Senes are almot gone, occaioned from over-whelming Perplexities; for which, and all Dicontents, vain Fears, foolih Fanta â€¢ es and Imaginations, which dicompoe and enlave
the Mind, hurry and diorder the Spirits, thereby hurting the Brain, impairing the Memory, Sight, Hearing, &c. it has been experienc'd, to do more than many other Medicines of greater repute.

It comforts and trengthens the Brain and Nerves powerfully, refrehes the Senitive Faculties, relieves the Animal Spirits, being excellent alo in everal other Dieaes of the Head, whether recent or inveterate; as Stuffings of the Head, Colds, Catarrhs or defluxions of Rheum, whether upon, the Eyes, Noe, Teeth, Palate, &c. cures the Palie of the Tongue, running Sores or Impothumes in the Ears, being admirable againt Deafnes or thicknes of Hearing, noie and pains in the Ears, &c. wellings of the Throat, Jaws, and the like, from a defluxion of Humours.

It is a certain Remedy in the Apoplexy both for Prevention and Cure (that Ditemper of late being very frequent and fatal) and will do more in that cae than any Peron is aware, if it be inwardly taken, and outwardly us'd in the beginning of the Dieae, and reiterated in the Intervals of time, as neceity requires; it dicuing Flatulencies, aborbing the Acid Humour, which are many times the original Caues of the Dieae, attracting or drawing away the Morbifick Matter from the Parts affected, detroying and carrying it off the right way, that the the like can carcely be done by any other Medicines.

In the Megrim, Vertigo, Giddines or Swimming in the Head, and in the mot cruel, vehement and inveterate Head-achs, they do wonders, taking away the Pain in many Perons in 3 or 4 minutes time, and that with the ue of it inwardly taken, and a little nuft up the Notrils, and the Head, Temples, Forehead and behind the Ears being bathed therewith, and that o perfectly, as never to return more from that preent Caue: This I can aure you upon my own Experience; for they radically cure after all other things have been found ineffectual, and when the hope of Cure has been pat, by removing the caue or occaion thereof; without doubt in the caes of an
old and vehement Head-ach, Giddines, Swimming &c. whether continual, or coming by Fits, it has no equal in the whole World. This Tincture, and the Englih Pills before mentioned, cured a Woman that had the Head-ach from her Minority, o violently ometimes, that it was thought he would be ditracted, and at all times o extream, as to make Life very uncomfortable and unfit for the doing of any Buines, and, this was done with only two Boxes of Pills and two Bottles of the Tincture, tho' he had gone through Coures of Phyick, with Blitering, Cupping, Shaving, &c. for near 20 Years together to little or no purpoe.

In the Palie and Dead-Palie, as ome call it, it is the greatet and noblet Medicament known; for being taken inwardly, and alo ued outwardly, it takes away the benumednes of the Parts, and retores its Sene and feeling; curing the haking or trembling of the Head and Members, ariing from weaknes and relaxation of the Nerves, caued either by old Age or a coldnes of Humours, and o trengthens thoe Parts affected, that they eem to put new life into them again.

Nor do know, or believe there can be, any equal to it for the Cure of the Epilepie, or Falling Sicknes, and that not only in Children (proceeding from Faults of the Stomach, Wind, corrupted Food, Worms, &c.) but alo in elder Perons, it having cured in both Sexes of 20, 30 and 40 Years of Age, having done o great Cures of that kind, which hould they be related, they would not eaily be believed, except by thoe who were Eye-witnees of the ame; and likewie it cures Convulion Fits almot to a Miracle; for it digets that pituitous Humour which o much abounds in uch Perons, by exciting their inward heat and trengthening the Brain, which is in many Perons the caue of this Dieae, it eparating, and conuming in the Stomach and Bowels thoe Acrid and Malign Vapours which acend to the Brain, and which by pricking with their harp Points the Membranes and Nervous Filaments, excite and induce this terrible Dieae.

This Medicine by its ubtle and penetrative Particles enter into the very ubtance of the Nerves, opens their Pores, removes their Obtructions, refrehes and caues a free coure and circulation of the Animal Spirits, it acuates or harpens all the Senes, both internal and external, facilitates and expedites the motions of the Members thro' the whole Body.

And by taking this Tincture inwardly, and uing it at the ame time outwardly, warms, comforts and trengthens the Brain and Nerves after a very wonderful manner, thereby helping the weaknes of the Sight, trengthning the Eyes, fortifying the viive Faculties and Nerves, and multiplies and clears the Animal and Viive Spirits, taking away Darknes, Clouds, Vapours, &c. which obfucates the Sight, or obtructs the Optick Nerves.

But during taking the Tincture in all the everal caes before poken of, it is neceary now and then to purge gently with the Englih Pills aforemention'd; which, together with the Tincture, performs after a wonderful manner, and proves thereby the mot abolute and exquiite Method that the World can afford.

Alo in Pains of the Head, Megrim, Apoplexies, Palies, and all other the Ditempers of the Brain and Nerves for outward ue, pour a little of it into the Palm of your Hand and nuff it up your Notrils, doing o twice or thrice in a day, and in extremities oftner, bathing alo ome of it in with your Hand all over the Head, Neck, Forehead, Temples, upon the Eye-brows, behind the Ears, rubbing it in without the ue of any Fire; it will ink in almot as fat as you lay it on, and will admirably comfort the Head and Brain; trengthen the Sight, and perform wonderful Cures, and that more eecially, if you Purge now and then with the Englih Pills.

In the Tooth ach or Defluxions upon the Jaws, Palate, &c. by holding a little in the Mouth, and nuffing ome up the Notrils as aforeaid, 'tis a preent help, and by dropping a few Drops into the Ears twice in a Day, putting in a little Cotton or Wool dipt in the ame a little warm'd, 'twill be an admirable Remedy in Pains of the Ears, Deafnes, Noie, &c.

The Virtues of the aid Englih Pills and Tincture in one other particular Ditemper, I cannot but take notice of, their Effects being o very remarkable; and that is, in the mot violent and extream Collicks or racking griping Pains of the Bowels and Stomach, even when the Patient hath been at the point of Death, rolling, tumbling about and roaring out with Pain, as if ditracted; four of the Pills being taken, and 100 or 150 Drops, or more, of the Tincture mix'd in a Glas of Sack or White Wine hot or mull'd, drank immediately after them, gives intant Eae, even upon the pot, when Glyters and all other Medicines have been ineffectual, and comforts and heals the Bowels o, that the Patient in half an Hours time after, is as if nothing had ailed him; they being of great power to uppres Wind and Humours that fly upwards, by which may be een their Excellency in defending the Head from obnoxious Fumes, &c. which o frequently indipoe it; and alo 50 or 60 Drops of the Tincture taken

A few Drops nufft up the Noe, eaes the mot violent Pains thereof in a Moment, and that without neezing or endangering Cold; and for that very ue, it is carcely to be expres'd the wonderful and intant Eae it gives; for no ooner is it nufft up the Noe, but the Pain is gone, tho' before it was never o intollerable, and by continuing, prevents its return, having cur'd old inveterate Head-achs of many Years tanding, in an intant, which long coures of Phyick were not able to do.

div.head: THE Balamick Retorative ELIXIR FOR Dieaes of the Lungs, whether Conumptions, Atma's, Phtyicks, &c.

div.head: AN Englih Vegetable For all Sorts of AGUES.
div.p: THERE are divers orts of Agues, which are ditinguih'd according to the difference there is in their intermiion, &c. Some are Quotidian Agues, or Simple Quotidian, that come daily, and that not with vehemen â€¢ Cold at the firt, but cold and colder by degrees, nor is the hot Fit very exceive: The Thirt in uch is but mall, the Urine white or thin, and watery, or thick and troubled; and the hot Fit generally lats eighteen Hours, and ometimes with Vomiting of Phlegm. Thee Fits oftentimes eize the Patient in the Night-time, and is frequently dangerous, becaue its continuance being long, is more ubject to degenerate into a Cachexie, Dropy or Lethargy. Hippocrates ays, That it is more dangerous if it comes in the Day-time, than if it comes in the Night. It is the Stomach that is for the mot part afflicted in thee Agues, becaue, as aid before, the Patient in the Fit is ometimes inclin'd to Vomit, which when done, gives relief.

Others are double Quotidian Agues, or every Day Agues, returning twice in Twenty-four Hours, with Coldnes of the extream Parts; but there is went to be no hivering Fit, or but very little; the Symptoms are otherwie the ame as in the Simple
Quotidian afore poken of, and caus'd alo chiefly from the Stomach, but reduplicate and tronger, holding commonly longer and more tedious, unles ome eminent Critical Evacuation intervene; and as the Caues are reduplicate, o do they hew more danger than the Simple Quotidian; and if it continues long, does rarely fail degenerating into ome other chronick and tedious Dieae, and more particularly into a Dropy.

Others are Tertian Agues, or Agues of the third Day, and comes with vehement cold or rigorous haking Fit, as tho' the Patient were pricked, follow'd with a hot Fit and other Symptoms; the Pule is equal, and anon a violent heat increaeth, with great Thirt, and ometimes vomiting of Choler, with reddih Urine; giving the Patient very great uneaines, dreading every Fit, which oftetimes is more than other, hifting as to times, keeping no periodical Paroxims, but comes o uncertainly, that the Patient knows not in that Day what time to expect it. The haking coldnes at firt coming is vehement and harp, the heat and burning in the hot Fit is alo violent and trong, preading it elf over the whole Body in the heigtht of the Fit; and towards the end of the hot Fit, the whole Body is in a gentle Sweat. Thee ort of Agues holding not above the fourth Fit, other times not above the eventh, each Fit holding not above Twelve Hours, and is without much danger, unles Malignity be joyn'd with it; and if breakings out on the Lips, Scabs or a Loones happens, it is very healthful, becaue they are critical, tho' thee are Malign and Petilential Tertians, which, tho' they have evident Intermiions as the others, yet do often kill the Patient; beides, many accidents may fall in upon a Tertian Ague, uch as a Surfeit, violent Cold, &c. which may breed danger, tho' the Ague may have none of it elf.

Other Agues there are called Semi-tertian, which whether they be exquiite, that is, where Choler and Phlegm equally abound, vexing the Patient continually, but the third Day with a haking Fit, or Spurious, wherein either Choler or Phlegm mot abounds; if the firt, repreent chiefly a Tertian, if the latter, a Quotidian,
of which we have poken before; yet thee caue no great Thirt or Burning, but ometimes is attended with an inflamation of ome Vicera, or Bowels, as Stomach, Liver, Spleen, or Parts adjacent, which is caus'd when the Feverih Matter is carried thither with the Blood. The Semiter-tian Ague, both exquiite and purious (for they differ chiefly in degree) are both dangerous, becaue thereby the Stomach and Nervous Parts are very much affected, and is attended with almot a continuil burning Fever; but epecially the exquiite, being there is a drynes of the Tongue, Thirt, Swooning, Watching, and ometimes raving and dead Sleep, and is what Hippocrates account amongt acute Dieaes, and continues long; Avicen ays even Months, and at lat ends frequently in a Hectick.

There is alo the double Tertian Ague, which comes once or twice a Day, two Days together, leaving the Patient free one Day between. Some Authors mention a triple Tertian, where there are three Fits in two Days, and one Day clear between; but is reckon'd to be eldom een, and les eaie to be dicover'd by a Phyician, tho' he had Argus's Eyes. Thee Agues are chiefly of Humours gather'd together in the Liver, Gall, Stomach, Meentery, Pancreas, or in the Veins of thoe Parts. In this Ague it is a hard Matter to get a convenient time for the giving Medicine to Cure, becaue oftentimes there is no long; pace beetween the two Fits; for ometimes the Fits hold o long, that the one begins before the other is ended, being thereby much more dangerous than a Semi-tertian, becaue it comes from a reduplication of the Caue.

The next is the Quarian Ague, or Ague that comes every fourth Day, and is accompanied with vehement Cold as if it would nip and break the Bones; the Pulle is flow in the beginning of the Fit, and afterwards the Melancholly Humour by little and little is inflam'd, whence comes a burning or hot Fit; the Urine is white, thin and watery, with two Days intermiion each Fit; and when the Fit is coming, it caues reachings and yawning, with a haking Fit: at firt mall, but afterwards extream, yet not o much pricking, as rendring the
Patient as if he were beat or bruiel; the Caue is from Melancholly and adult Humours, known by decaying the Appetite, cauing great Chirts, and Head and Back ach. Thee ort of Agues are of all of them, of longet continuance, handling a Patient ometimes half a Year or a Year, or if it happen in the fall of the Leaf, two Years or longer; and is ometimes dangerous, epecially if it degenerates into a continual Quartan, or happens to afflict People of Sixty Years of Age or upwards

There is alo the Compound Quartan Ague, which is either double or triple: in the double, the Fit leaves the Patient two Days free, and comes the next two Days; in the triple, the Paroxim returns three Days together, leaving two Days free after them, as in a Quotidian and double Tertian; thee come of Melancholly. Putrifying in divers parts of the Body, and are dangerous, if not in time cured, being ele apt to degenerate into chronick, inveterate and incurable Dieaes, and that becaue the Fit o often returns; it emaciates and wates the Body exceedingly, conuming the radical Moiture, depreing the Spirits, obtructing the Natural, Vital and Animal Functions, and at lat brings the Body into an incurable Hectick, Conumption or Dropy: But if the Ague be taken in time, and it happens to a young trong Peron, and proper Medicines be exhibited, there may be no great doubt of a Cure; but if it happens to an old Peron, who is weak of Nature, and that in the Winter alo, it is deperate, and if cannot oon be got off, but contiues long, will prove Mortal.

Thus have I run through the Nature and Caues of the ditinct orts of Agues, and which, as all Authors oberve, are generally to be cured by the ame Clas of Medicines, only regarding the Strength and Contitution of the Patient.

The Englih Vegetable and Plaiters, at firt mentioned, eldom or never fail, if us'd together, to cure the mot inveterate and chronick ort, provided they both be made ue of in time, before Nature is too much depres'd by the everity of the Dieae, and yet
even in People that were Young, and not Old, they have effected the Cure, which before had baffled Jeuits Powder, the Bitters, Alteratives, &c. And in thoe Agues of late tanding, the Vegetable alone has cured without the Plaiter, and in ome the Plaiter without the Vegetable; but where the Cae is evere, to expedite the Cure, I generally ue both; but ome, (epecially Children) cannot be gotten to take any inward Medicine at all, and there the applying the Plaiters mot commonly does, only mut be renewed more times than there would be occaion, if the Vegetable was taken alo at the ame time.

div.head: Directions for taking the Vegetable Powder, and applying the Plaiters.
div.p: A Man or Woman may take a whole Paper at a time, which mut always be taken in a Glas of hot Wine, an Hour or two before the Fit, and be cover'd up warm; whereupon it will caue in ome gentle Vomiting and Sweat, in others only Sweat, in others will only work by Urine, but which way oever it operates, it never falls hort of expectation, curing almot all Agues without uing any thing ele; but where the Cae is inveterate, and has been of long tanding, we are forc'd to apply the Plaiters alo, which I hall by and by give Directions about.

One of 12 or 15 Years of Age, may take two thirds of a Paper: thoe of younger Years in proportion, always giving it in Wine as before directed; and is to be repeated to every one for 5 or 6 times, more or les, as the Ague is evere, or has been of longer or horter continuance, tho' not one Ague in twenty requires its being taken above three times.

Note, There is no occaion to drink any thing with it, more than the few Spoonfuls of Wine, jut to mix it and make it drinkable, which may be White Wine or any other Wine, proportioning the quantity, as the Patient is either a grown Peron or Child. A grown
Peron taking it in 6 or 8 Spoonfuls, and always as hot as it can be well drank.

The Plaiters to the Writs, mut be prepared and applyed thus: To all the Powder in the Box and the whole Yolk of a new laid Egg, which mix and beat up well together in a Mortar or Porringer â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢
rating them well together, adding o much <â€¦>
and tronget Vineger as will be ufficient to make it into uch a conitency as Venice Treacle is; then pread it pretty thick upon a Linnen Cloth of 2 or 3 Inches broad for a grown Peron, but narrower for Children, which apply upon the Pules of both Writs, tying them on, o as not to come off, where they mut remain without changing them, for nine Days, becaue this Remedy exerts its vertues but by degrees. And it ought to be applyed an Hour or half an Hour before the Fit comes, and if the Ague be not cur'd in nine Days, to be laid on afreh.
The Price of the Vegetable Powder is 2s. 6d. a Paper, and the Box of Powder for Plaiters is 3 s. 6d. both to be had at the Place afore-mentioned.

Note, Thee Plaiters to the Writs frequently, I may ay generally, Cure all forts of Agues (unles they be of very long tanding indeed, and attended with other Indipoitions) without any inward Medicine at all, but where there is a complication of Infirmities, beides the Ague, that the Stomach is foul and Blood injur'd, there is a neceity for an inward Medicine, than which nothing can exceed the Vegetable Powder before-mentioned, and will do a hundred times more Service, and is a thouand times more afer than Jeuits Bark, or any other Medicine whatoever.

div.head: Hydragogue Tincture: OR, DROPS, Purging away Water, thereby curing Dropies of all orts.
div.p: BEFORE I peak of the excellent Vertues of thee Drops, I hall ay omething of the everal pecies of Dropies, which, as they affect diverly, so go under divers appellations, as the Acites, Tympanites and Anaarca.

The Acites, or Hydrops Abdominis, is in Englih, the Watery Dropy in the Belly, and is always attended with a tretching of the Belly, by reaon of the uperabounding of ferous, watery and alt Humours, cat forth into the capacity of the Abdomen, through fault of the Liver, Spleen and Reins, cauing alo the Feet, Thigh â€¢ , and in Men ometimes the Cods to well, and is known by the welling of the Belly, a difficulty of Breathing, and the hoare ound of the Belly if truck, like as if a Bladder half full was truck upon; alo upon compreing the Belly with the Fingers, it pits and leaves the print of them thereon; and if the Patient turns from ide to ide, a Noie like the murmuring or waving of Water is heard, and the Water by continuance there, will in time putrify and corrupt the Bowele, caue a Fever and Thirt, and wate the Patients
Strength and Spirits: Therefore all imaginable care ought to be taken to evacuate the Water in time, both by Stool and Urine, or ele the Patient will dye; and if let alone o long as that the Patient's Strength be pent, not being able to bear Purging Medicines; then Tapping mut be ued, as the only preent way to ecure the Patient, if that Method will do it.

The Tympanites, or Windy Dropy, hews it elf alo by a ditention or tretching of the Belly; but as the other contains Water within the capacity of the Abdomen, this contains only Wind, which o ditends the Belly, that it being truck upon with the Hand, ounds like a Drum, and is rather more well'd than the watery Dropies, and the Navel hangs out, but will not leave any impreion upon preing it with the Fingers; the Patient is mot afflicted with Pain about the Navel and Loins in Windy Dropies like a Cholick, when there is no uch Pain in a watery one, and is eaier to be cured, and of les danger.

The Anaarca, or Leucophlegmatia, is a Dropy of the whole Habit of the Body, the Water being dipered, o that all the Fleh appears moit, woln and wet, wherein not only the Hands, Arms; Breat, Face, Thighs, Legs and Feet well, but the whole Body alo, whereby, if you make a preure with your Finger into the Fleh in any part, it will pit and leave an impreion.

The caue of this Dieae is chiefly Cold, or by very plentifully drinking cold Water, or Small Beer, or ele proceeds from a defect of the Liver, or defect of Natural Heat, Obtructions and imbicility of the Stomach, from whence a collection of pituitous and watery Humours is produced, and univeral Cachexy.

If this Dieae be recent, and in a young Peron, it is not difficult to cure: In Perons aged, it is very doubtful, if not deperate and indeed uch as are much in Years eldom find a Cure for it: But yet the Vertues of the Hydragogue Tincture are uch, as that it has cured everal Elderly People by being follow'd for
ome continuance, which they mut, tho' it is what ome will not be prevail'd upon to do, being oon weary of the bet of Medicines, if â€¢â€¢ ey find not immediate Relief, when the continuance of the Medicine would to all appearance have cured them: Therefore it is advied, that all People that have the Dropy, or are Dropically inclin'd, take the Drops contantly as directed, and then a Cure may be expected.

div.head: Directions for the taking of the Hydragogue Tincture.
div.p: THE Patient is to take from 15 to 20, 30, 40, 50 or 60 Drops, more or les, as they operate by Urine or Stool, taking them always in White Wine, wherein Mutard Seed or Hore-radih Roots have been teeped; but if they purge much, a les Doe mut be taken; if they do not purge at all, a greater Doe; and will alo work by Urine plentifully, tho' at the firt taking them they may eem to give frequent occaions to Urine, and but little come; but after a little waiting the Urine will come plentifully, and the Patient be reliev'd. They are to be taken every Night and Morning, and alo in the middle of the Day, if there be occaion.
The Price is 3 s. 6 d. the Bottle. To be had only at the Place before mentioned.

div.head: The mot Famous Eye-Powder & Water IN THE WORLD.
div.p:
THE Eye is a tender part, and is oon injur'd by extraneous Bodies, as alo by Humours flowing upon them from within the Body; and as thoe injure them one way, o oftentimes does wrong Medicines the other, nay, make the Cae more deperate, o that the Remedy proves wore than the Dieae, whence comes Cataracts and Blindnes; for many People grow dim-ighted and dark by Humours upon the Eyes, which at length breed Spots, Films, Skins, Clouds, Webs, and the like, which grow over the Sight, the fore-runners of which are Atoms, Flys, Gnats, H â€¢ irs, Threads, &c. flying or wimming before them, and which if not remedied in time, increae to Cataracts, the couching of which ometimes cures, but oftner â€¢ ot nay, frequently ruins the Sight for ever, as many can too truly Witnes; now thee Spots, Films, Skins, etc. tho' aid by Oculits to be incurable but by Couching; they telling their Patients they mut wait till they come to ripe Cataracts to be couch'd, are to be cur'd without, even tho' grown to ripe Cataracts, and that by blowing a little of a afe Powder, and uing a Water into the Eyes, the continual uing of which will often and wear a way gradually that Skinny or filmy Subtance, which is a Humour congeal'd; and diolves and abforbs
the gros vicid Humours that upplies and gives rie to thoe Films, &c. to the perfect retoration of the Sight, whereby not one in a hundred that ues it, would ever tand in need of being couch'd, or would ever have their Sight impair'd or injur'd by Humours, Spots, Skins, Films, or the like; but to the contrary, keep off Humours, clears and trengthens the Sight, that all that once ue them, will recommend to all they know; for they are uch innocent Medicines, as that they may be taken inwardly, and have done uch notable Cures, as are to be wonder'd at, even in all orts of Indipoitions of the Eyes, whether they before, running, hot or inflam'd, and that when Purgings, Bleedings, Bliterings, Cuppings, Iues and Seatons have been us'd to no purpoe.

div.head: Directions for uing the Eye Powder and Water.
div.p: IF the Eyes be very ore, tender, well'd, hot or inflam'd, the Water alone will be ufficient, without the Powder, wahing with it 2, 3 or 4 times a Day or oftener, as there may be occaion, but if there be no Humour, but Spots, Films, Skins or the like, there the Powder mut be ued alo, a little of it being to be blown into the Eyes 3 or 4 times a Day, daily, till well, and the Eyes to be wah'd an Hour after it with the Water; but if the Powder or Water hould occaion any mart, as in weak tender Eyes they may (tho' without the leat injury) then it is to be ued eldomer, and then they will be bearable. It is admirable to find how they comfort, clear and trengthen the Sight, and remove all Humours, Spots, Films, &c. that darken, or obfucate the Sight; and if People that have weak tender Eyes, and are fearful of Cataracts or Blindnes, the ue of it in time will prevent any uch bad Indipoition, or dimnes or weaknes of Sight.
The Price of the Powder is 2s. 6d. the Paper, the Water 3s. 6d. both to be had at the Place before mentioned, and no where ele.

div.head: THE CARMINATIVE: OR, Wind Expelling LOZENGES.
div.p:
THE mot famous Medicine for the expelling of Wind, ever known, they keep the Wind out of the Stomach, if one of them be held in the Mouth in a Morning or any other time in the Day, and are more ready and much more wholeome, as well as beneficial, than Cordial Drams; for thee break away the Wind pent up in the Stomach and Bowels, and trengthen them, creating an Appetite, and not detroying it as Drams do; beides, they keep the Body o olutive, as thoe that take them will never be cotive; but always open. In the Cholick, Gripes, Stitches in the Sides, Windy Vapours that oppres the Head, owr Belchings, Hiccups, &c. they are admirable; if taken after Eating, they caue good Digetion, and rectify all Indigetions and Diorders of the Stomach; purifying the Blood, curing Heart-burn, making the Breath weet, and do render the whole Body and Mind, chearful, lightome and eay; being really a pretty neceary Companion, in cae of
ill Scents, bad Air, &c. and o delightful and pleaant to the Tate, as well well as helpful to the health, that none that once try them, will ever be without them.

It is only putting one of them into the Mouth at a time, and wallowing it as it diolves, and o do as often in a Day as you pleae. The Price is Two Shillings and Six Pence a Box, which will lat a long time, and are only to be had at the Place aforementioned.

div.head: A BALSAM To Make ISSUES Run; Which is alo good to cleane old Sores, Ulcers, Wounds, &c.
div.p: THIS Medicine is fit and neceary for all Families, on the acccout of Hurts, Sores, Wounds, Ulcers, &c. as for the making Iues run; for if a little of it be pread upon Linit or Tow, and applied to the Sore Place, it wonderfully cleanes it, that a little Diachylon Plaiter afterwards will be ufficient to heal it.
